Award.AwardTitle: Social influences on the Long-term Cessation of Violence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social Influences on the Long-term Cessation of Violent Behaviors

In spite of increased interest in how individuals modify their behaviors in ways that promote health, little prior research has examined the process of moving away from the use of violence within intimate relationships. Intimate partner violence (IPV) is a leading cause of injury, particularly in young adult populations, and is associated with declines in emotional well-being. Despite the importance of the topic, there are few prior studies of how to decrease IPV. Those studies have been short-term and their explicit links to treatment programs has generally been limited to the emphases of these programs. The current study will provide a perspective on continuity and change in the experience of IPV over the different stages of life, and investigate the role of social experiences as influences on what causes changes in these types of behaviors. Most theories of change highlight the importance of the individual's own motivation and receptivity as key components of the change process. Unlike those studies, this study's focus on potentially malleable social factors will provide new insights about specific social and environmental influences that serve as catalysts for behavioral changes. Knowledge about these linkages has the potential to inform the design of more effective prevention and intervention efforts targeting this serious public health problem.

Using a life-course perspective, the study will build on a five-wave longitudinal investigation of a large, diverse sample of young men and women interviewed first as adolescents, and later as they have navigated the transition to adulthood (Toledo Adolescent Relationships Study). At each interview, information was collected about IPV perpetration, as well as about family, peer, romantic partner and neighborhood experiences and influences. The research will follow-up for an additional assessment all those respondents who reported using violence within the context of an intimate relationship during the course of the study (n=403). Specific objectives are to: a) document patterns of persistence and "desistance" of these behaviors, b) investigate the underlying mechanisms associated with the process of making and sustaining positive changes, and c) identify social and individual factors that distinguish desisters and those who continue this negative pattern within their relationships. The relatively long time gap between assessments (5 years) will permit an examination of sustained behavior change, as distinguished from the relatively common phenomenon of temporary lulls. In addition to the online structured data collection effort, the researchers will complete in-depth qualitative interviews with a subset of male and female respondents who vary in the character of their experiences with violence (n=85). This mixed method approach will permit a comprehensive examination of the complex interplay of social experiences and individual-level subjective changes as factors associated with the successful cessation of this form of interpersonal violence. This research contributes to scholarship about desistance from crime and contributes to the design of more effective programs to prevent and intervene in intimate partner violence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While positive changes have occurred in general public awareness about the problem of intimate partner violence (IPV), this form of violence continues to occur, and exacts significant costs to individuals and families. The current study contributed to the emerging science of behavior change by focusing on: a) the extent to which individuals had ?desisted? from the perpetration of previous violence within their intimate relationships, and b) the factors associated with a sustained pattern of cessation of these destructive forms of interpersonal conflict. This multimethod project benefited from a longitudinal design, and specific focus on those in the sample (330 respondents who averaged 32 years of age) who had reported IPV perpetration at earlier waves of interviews. Results indicated that approximately two-thirds had avoided perpetration in their most recent relationship, while one-third reported continued perpetration. The majority (85%) of those who persisted indicated that they were both victims and perpetrators of violence in their most recent relationships. Analyses also revealed that nearly half (48%) of the sample reported no history of physical fights within a relationship, even though they had at earlier interview waves reported some form of violence perpetration. This high level of recanting indicates the value of longitudinal designs rather than relying exclusively on retrospective reports. Respondents who reported lower frequencies of IPV perpetration more often recanted and those who were engaged in IPV more recently were less likely to recant. Potentially reflecting the distinctively gendered meanings and differential social responses to this form of violence, greater shares of men recanted relative to women in the perpetration group. Analyses of questions that tapped reasons for making changes indicated that several conventional understandings about IPV (need to stay away from drugs and alcohol, fear of arrest) were not often endorsed by these ?desisting? respondents. Instead, those who reported shifting away from violence in their recent relationships often endorsed relationship and social considerations and effects (e.g., feelings of commitment to the partner desire to maintain the respect of family and friends, concerns about children). The in-depth interviews with a subset of these respondents provided important details about each of these areas, and how they may be connected in the life experiences of specific individuals. These narratives sometimes emphasized fundamental changes in the type of partner they desired or had chosen, and in other instances shifts in styles of communicating or behavior changes (no longer being unfaithful, not tolerating infidelity) associated with reductions in flashpoints for heightened conflict within their relationships. Developing a zero tolerance of violence itself was another theme that emerged from the narrative data.   

The majority (60%) of those who were classified as IPV ?desisters? were ?very confident? they would avoid violence in their relationships in the future. Nevertheless, the subgroup of current persisters along with a significant number of individuals who indicated less than complete confidence underscore the need for continued research and policy attention to the factors associated with more favorable long-term outcomes. Taken together, the qualitative and quantitative results highlight that even though taking personal responsibility for one?s own actions is a cornerstone of programs designed to affect change, it is likely that increased attention to relational and other social dynamics remain important components of movement away from this form of violent behavior.
